reviewText: Doctor Who Season 5 ReviewOnce again, this isn't specifically a review of the individual shows on this box set, or of the program itself, but more of a review as to the faults and ignorant oversights as to what it doesn't offer, compared to previous box sets from seasons 1-4.  If you need to know the specifics of this product, content, and episode by episode break down, there are plenty of web sites out there just for that. And if that is all you're looking for from this review, then I humbly suggest that you skip this and continue to read anything from elsewhere.And now for those who care for something more insightful...For starters, I payed for this, and as such, I don't want to be inundated with commercials!  After you get through all the legal stuff, and the 2|entertain and BBC logos, there are commercials for various programs on most of the discs, and for BBC America.  Personally, I feel that since I am PAYING for this program, I should be able to watch said program without having to watch any commercials.  And this shouldn't apply only to this release, but to all future releases no matter what the show or show or movie is.Getting past that initial irritation, you should know that there is one major feature, or lack thereof, and that being there is no "Select Episode" option, only "Play All."  But after some time, and I admit, by accident, I discovered that if you use the "Select Scene" option, you can watch individual episodes.  But for anyone to not include a "Select Episode" option on the main menu is either lazy or incompetent.Also, there is no 3-D trailer, and I know for a fact that one was made.  You can watch it on YouTube.  So why not include it?  The one on YouTube requires the green and red glasses, but nonetheless, they should at least make it an option for those who care to get those specs and enjoy that trailer.  And since I'm on the subject of trailers, if all that was lacking isn't enough, the "Coming Next" trailer at the end of each episode has been eliminated from the original broadcast.  Now to be honest, I always skipped past this, but for the purists out there, since it was part of the show then, it should be included now.  If the BBC doesn't want to do the "Coming Next" clip at the end of the episodes for season six, then fine, at least we won't be missing anything that didn't already air.  Just don't pull a George Lucas or Steven Spielberg by continually changing that which has already been broadcast.As for the, behind the scenes, geeks like me, there are only In Vision commentaries for select episodes.  I remember the good old days, about, oh, two years ago, when there used to be commentaries for all episodes in previous seasons, either In Vision or standard audio.  Adding insult to injury, said same commentaries for this season are in many aspects an ego boost for Moffat, and are filmed as a straight forward shot of those participating, which sort of looks like a police line up.  And even worse than that, those participating, quite frankly, look bored.  And if you didn't think it could get any worse, (hello wound, would you care for some salt?) the two parters only have a commentary for one of the two parts!  Seriously, can't you people finish what you start, or in some cases, start what you finish?  And while it's unfortunate that Matt Smith didn't participate in any of the commentaries, Karen (Amy) and (Arthur) Rory, were in the last one with the director, and that was really the only one that was enjoyable to listen to as well as watch, while they reacted to the episode.Now for the worst part.  On the technical aspect, the damn thing gets jack up during the In Vision commentaries unless the screen resolution is manually reset to a specific setting.  It was only after reading another customers' review did I learn that some players need to be manually set to a specific screen resolution in order to avoid this problem.  (1080i)  This is all due to the fact that the Blu-Ray version wasn't remastered for players outside the UK, and so, there is a chance that, even with updating your Blu-Ray player, you may not be able to enjoy everything that this box set has to offer.  Again, this is all due to laziness on behalf of those the pressed these and allowed their distribution.Finally, there is the last disc which contains the Confidentials...  They are not listed as being cut, but you can bet the tin dog that they are just that.  While the originals averaged roughly 43 minutes in length, those presented on the Blu-Ray are averaging 12 minutes!  One would think that since Blu-Ray discs hold considerably more data than DVDs, they should have been presented if not wholly, then at least more complete than these whittled down thumbnails.So in conclusion, while I profess to still be an avid fan of Doctor Who, I loath the ad infused, content diluted product, which I payed for.  The DVD set is cheaper, and has no fewer features than the Blu-ray, so I would regard that as a better buy.  Or, if all you wish to do is watch the bare bones of each episode, then purchase the individual shows through On Demand, or Amazon, or anything, and save even more money, since you won't be getting much of anything elsewhere.

reviewText: As much as I loved Series 3 and 4, and I do think series 4 was the best, at the same times they were a bit of a chore to watch. I mean, they did get progressively darker and uglier and at times downright depressing. But they had some extraordinary episodes. I'll never forget being held by the neck by the suspense of Midnight or scared to walk down the hallway of my house at night after watching "Blink". Sadly, the specials (or the "Let's get another year out of Tennant and Davies whether they like it or not" episodes) were garbage. Aside from "Waters of Mars", the Doctor did nothing but bitch and moan and whine, and I was glad to see him go. But I won't lie, his final scene was a bit heart wrenching, because the Doctor I knew and loved, despite being annoyed by his whininess in those last episodes, was leaving. But, when Matt Smith appeared for the first time in that last episode, my kind changed about him completely. I thought he was not going to live up, because DT set standards way too high. And maybe he did. But I was charmed by his suaveness, hilarity and perkiness within that short appearance, and immediately I sprung to "The Eleventh Hour" without hesitation.Simply put, Matt Smith is a winner. Sure, he's no David Tennant. But he doesn't try to be David Tmennat either- after all, if he tried aping the winning formula, it wouldn't be good, right? It would be sour and boring. Thankfully, Matt Smith does take a page or two from other actors books, but gives it his own spin too. He portrays The Doctor as someone who is almost always positive and thinks "it can get much worse". Sure he does have a few moments where you can tell he's seen death, but he chooses not to angst and realizes that Time Lords have long lives for a reason. His catch phrases like "Bow ties are cool" and "Geronimo!!!!!!" are pure winners and are absolutely hilarious. And when he smiles, we smile. He is fun, charming, suave, persuasive, and flamboyant, which is truly refreshing.His companions are equally fun. Amelia Pond is a beautiful and fun girl who has a great sense of humour and doesn't take herself too seriously. She has a cute Scottish accent and a lot of hilarious one liners, and she helps make the episodes fun to watch. Her fianceé Rory is played by the handsome and charming Arthur Darvill, who does have to put up with Amy's constant sarcasm and sort of let's her walk all over him, but it's funny. He himself has some funny lines, like near the end of "Vampires of Venice", when he uses the following to defend Amy: "This way you ugly... spongebob... the only thing uglier was your-- mum...".The episodes? Admittedly this season does start rather slowly, but around episode 3, it really gets going, and when it does, it's a roller coaster. River Song returns for a couple episodes (including the Pandorica ones) and she is great to watch- sassy, full of class, and badass, with a lot of good jokes too. The weeping angels are back and this time they're everywhere. They're just as scary as they were in series 3 too. Really, I didn't not like any episodes in the season, as all of them were fun, and most were very fast paced.In short, I can't recommend this season enough. It's one of the best and the beginning of a era for The Doctor. Thank you Moffat for bringing new life to the show, and thanks to Smith for giving a fresh feel to The Doctor. Thanks to Gillan and Darvill for also providing excellent performances as the companions! And furthermore thanks to the Beeb for keeping Doctor Who alive!Now excuse me while I put my bow tie and fez on and cook up some nice hot fish sticks and custard too!
summary: Series 5 brings the FUN back to Doctor Who!

reviewText: Season Five of the reconstituted/reimaged Doctor Who was greatly anticipated, not just because of the transition from David Tennant to Matt Smith as The Doctor, but what direction Steven Moffat would take as the showrunner after--using the terminology I've used with this series--the Russell T. Davies chapter.  Smith--the youngest actor ever to play the TimeLord--brought an old-soul nature to the role.  If Tennant seemed to hearken to Tom Baker, Smith seemed to go all the way back to Patrick Troughton and William Hartnell; a little crotchety at times, but filled with the usual boundless energy and the lines flying at warp speed.The Companion to Smith's Eleventh Doctor is Karen Gillan's Amy Pond.  The immediate issue with Gillan--because of her red hair--is to immediately compare her to Catherine Tate.  Whereas Donna Noble was all mouth and "shoulders" (AHEM); Amy Pond is all eyes (brown and doe-eyed) and legs.  Not that she isn't mouthy, but Amy has NOTHING on Donna.  In this storyline, The Doctor first meets "Pond" (As he calls her sometimes) when she's seven, leaves for two minutes (his two minutes), but comes back to her 12 years later (Her 12 years), then, when she's ready to travel with him it's after a minute of his time--but two more years (And the night before she's supposed to get married) in her time (There WILL be a test on this later...).  Plus, there is the element of Amy's attraction to The Doctor, something that plays out at the end of the "The Time Of Angels/Flesh And Stone" two-parter.  This isn't a case of Amy having the feelings for The TimeLord that Rose Tyler or Martha Jones had...this is a Companion in heat.  Which leads to the first interesting twist in the Moffatt chapter...The first unique twist of this first part of the Moffatt chapter comes from Arthur Davrill's Rory Williams--Amy's fiancée, who ends up being a key part of this season; putting Rory into the TARDIS--which sort of gives the storyline a feel of Jack Harkness/Gwen Cooper/Rhys Williams from Torchwood.  Moffatt takes a very different tack here by very quickly giving this Doctor his family...it's just a little bit of a shock that the fourth member of this group is Alex Kingston's River Song--but make no mistake, it's a pleasant shock.  River was introduced in Series 4--the two-parter "Silence in The Library/Forest of The Dead"--as a woman who at some point, ends up being very important to The Doctor, but he currently keeps running into her out of order.  Kingston certainly brings a little bawdiness to the character--letting The Doctor know that he's about to run into her with the message, "Hello, Sweetie"--but the season finale--"The Big Bang"--also alerts the viewer that there's more to her than just being a Companion (Future wife?) to The Doctor.  Suffice it to say that (For those familiar with the Whoniverse) hearing a Dalek begging for mercy from a Companion...is a little different.  This series--with River's appearances in four episodes--allows for River to become the person pointing towards the impending dangers that The Doctor, Amy and Rory face, but she also shows her affection for her man.  The last scene between Kingston and Smith in "The Big Bang" is a hearty and passionate moment where River really starts letting her guard down to The Doctor...and gets cut short with her next warning of impending danger.There are many high points in this season--the opener, "The Eleventh Hour", in which Smith establishes his take on The Doctor, and the season's storyline gets set into motion..."The Beast Below" has the surprising and unique twist of Amy picking up on things early and stopping The Doctor from making a mistake--plus a great turn from Sophie Okonedo as "Liz Ten"...the aforementioned "The Time Of Angels/Flesh And Stone", which brings back The Weeping Angels from Season 3's "Blink";  "The Hungry Earth/Cold Blood" two-parter which begins the time paradox that is part of the season's climax;... but my absolute favorite story of this season is the episode "Vincent And The Doctor", where the TimeLord and Amy meet up with Vincent Van Gogh after seeing something out of place in one of his paintings at Musee D' Orsay in Paris.  It's a great turn by Tony Curran as the tortured artist...who develops a little bit of a thing for Amy...but what makes this episode is an uncredited performance by Bill Nighy as a curator/expert at D'Orsay who unknowingly lets an unpopular artist during his life know that he ends up being held in higher esteem in history.  It's a touching and brilliant scene, all at once heartbreaking and uplifting.  Nighy is just great, oblivious to the person near him; Curran is heartbreaking--finding out that his art is held in such high esteem after his departure.Overall, this first part of Moffatt's chapter allows Smith to establish is old soul in a young body ("Bow ties are cool..."), Amy to evoke some element of Donna Noble (Though Donna made the point that she wasn't a shag in the TARDIS early on to The Tenth Doctor) while being the ultimate hero of the season, Davrill to become something more than Noel Clarke's Mickey Smith from the Davies chapter, and Kingston to begin to add layers--both heroic and ominous--to River.  All in all, a good beginning to the Moffatt Chapter.
summary: Doctor Who Season 5--Smith Gives The Doctor Old Soul

reviewText: The fifth season (or series) of "Doctor Who" presented viewers with a number of changes. Head Writer/Executive Producer Russell T. Davies and Executive Producer Julie Gardner, who had successfully brought the show back to television in 2005, stepped down from their duties. Replacing them were Steven Moffatt, Piers Wenger and Beth Willis. The new creative team brought in many things, including a new look for both the interior and exterior of the Tardis, as well as a slightly different style to the stories they would tell. But biggest of all, they introduced us to a new Doctor: Number Eleven, played by relative newcomer Matt Smith.Smith's performance as the Eleventh Doctor is fascinating to watch. It's hard to explain exactly how he plays the Doctor, but he does so with a lot of energy and talent. He's joined on his adventures by Karen Gillan as the feisty redhead Amy Pond, who provides the Doctor with a companion willing to butt heads with him on occasion. Also joining them on occasion is Amy's fiance Rory, played by Arthur Darvill, and the mysterious River Song, once again played by Alex Kingston, reprising her role from the previous regular season.Steven Moffatt, no stranger to the world of the Good Doctor, has written several stories before, including the classic "Blink" and the two-part adventure "Silence in the Library/Forest of the Dead." As Head Writer for the new series, he's written six of the thirteen episodes. Five of those episodes (The premiere episode, "The Eleventh Hour;" the two-parter "The Time of Angels/Flesh and Stone" that sees the return of the creepy and sinister Weeping Angels; and the two-part finale "The Pandorica Opens/The Big Bang," where the Doctor faces his greatest challenge yet) are destined to become classics! The other standout episode is "Vincent and the Doctor," where the Doctor and Amy join Vincent van Gogh to fight an alien threat.The other episodes are good overall. However, there are two drawbacks to this season. The first is that the show suffers from a slight lack of cohesion. Unlike previous seasons, where all the episodes melded together well despite the many locations through time and space, this one tends to go all over the place without sticking together well. The other problem is Episode Three, "Victory of the Daleks." Although the episode is good overall, the unwelcome return of the Doctor's greatest enemy mars the whole endeavor, and  shows that the Daleks are quickly becoming stale.However, other than these problems, the new season of "Doctor Who" is strong overall, and bodes well for the show's future. The Blu-ray release is good as well, with terrific picture and sound, and a good amount of extras. Fans will definitely find this season of the show worth owning.Program/Blu-ray Grade: B+

reviewText: I'll admit I was a bit skeptical when I started watching the first two episodes of the fifth series for "Doctor Who". While Matt Smith is fine as the Doctor and brings his own quirky interpretation to the role, the writing for the first two episodes was, to be charitable, weak (in fact the second episode borrowed an idea from the pilot episode of "Star Trek: The next Generation" although to be fair "Star Trek: The Next Generation" "borrowed" the idea of the Borg so turn about seems to be fair play here.). I was surprised as writer Steven Moffatt had written the best episodes of the previous seasons in my opinion. Luckily, things picked up by the third episode set in World War Two where PM Winston Churchill unveils his own secret weapon to take out the Nazi's with unintended consquences and results.The transfer here looks better than any of the previous episodes on either DVD or Blu-ray. The first four series were shot on regular video and blacks looked more like very dark blues. The colors are quite good here. The fifth season looks quite nice in its high def premiere. If you've purchased the DVD I can't comment on the video quality as I haven't seen it.A couple of minor complaints--the two part episode involving the Weeping Angels are NOT on the same disc (and should be)and while audio is an improvement over some of the previous sets, dialogue is occasionally overwhelmed by the music IF you choose to listen to the 5.1 mix in stereo (the obvious solution would be to listen to it in 5.1 but some folks won't do that hence the warning).The extras are, as always, quite generous. "The Eleventh Hour", "Victory of the Daleks", "The Time of Angels", "The Vampires of Venice", "Cold Blood" and "The Big Bang" all feature pip commentary tracks. We get deleted scenes, outtakes, "Doctor Who Confidential", video diaries and "Monster Files" for various creatures. There are three collectable postcards included in the set as well. The booklet that was in previous editions has been eliminated replaced by credits on the cardboard fold out cover. I dislike this packaging compared to the previous ones but it isn't horrible. The cover is a lenticular image of Smith and his lovely co-star Karen Gilan who plays the Doctor's new companion Amy Pond."Doctor Who: The Complete Fifth Series" is a bit inconsistent but the best episodes here more than hold their own with the best of previous seasons.
summary: The fifth season starts off a bit wobbly but quickly finds its legs with a brand new Doctor and companion (Blu-ray review)

reviewText: Each doctor brings something different to the table so it's not easy to compare them.9th doctor: Christopher Eccleston was strong in showing the darkness of the last of the time lords, but when it came to showing light heartedness he would sometimes be caught forcing his facial expressions.10th doctor: David Tennant was strong in showing vulnerability and his sadness and lonliness was palpable to the audience. but again there was sometimes forcing of his facial expressions during scenes where he was showing intense shock or anger.11th doctor: Matt Smith does not force his acting at all. There's no pushing and it comes across as natural at all times. He is especially strong in showing the doctor's lighthearted madness.  For many this might make him the best performer out of the three and therefore the best doctor; however, he lacks vulnerability in his approach. With the two previous actors you could often see the despair, lonliness and fear that the doctor holds inside- for them the madness the doctor portrayed was often an attempt to hide these vulnerabilities.  Where as Matt Smith's doctor seems to just be somewhat mad...simply because he is mad.  And to his credit Smith portrays this very well actually, but it's not as interesting because it was the doctor's vulnerability that made him so easy to relate to even though he is an alien time lord from outer space that travels in a 1960's police box.  There are so many scenes where Smith chooses not to show any fear in the face of danger, while Tennant and Eccleston often did.  If the doctor isn't scared about what's about to happen then why should the audience care what's going to happen?  I found myself drifting in my attention sometimes.  The main problem I see is the writing in seasons 5 & 6 is significantly less interesting than it was during Tennant's reign as the doctor, which means Matt Smith has less rich material to work with. (Not always- "The God Complex" in season 6 for instance is a well written episode). Season 6 is better than Season 5 but in general I feel they are both just shadows of previous seasons.  The doctor is a very different character than he was before.  All of a sudden, "The doctor lies" all the time.  So what is he now, House M.D.??  The previous doctors didn't like lying at all and the few times he did lie about a serious issue it bothered him. When he lied and told Martha (season 3 motorway episode) that Gallifrey still existed he was struggling with his guilt the entire episode and said so- until the end of the episode where he admited the lie and told her the truth.  It doesn't fit dr. who and it just makes him less likeable.  This doctor Who doesn't seem like he has a different face, but rather that it's an entirely different character and show altogether.

reviewText: First: Amazon.com's "Watch it Now" downloads? I love 'em. With iTunes, I have to wait for a download to finish before I can start watching a new show, but not with Amazon. And that's how I watched the entirety of Season 5 of Dr. Who.Second: This season of Dr. Who was my first, and I do believe it's the closest I've come to seeing a perfect season of television. Considering what a TV addict I am--Buffy, Veronica Mars--that's saying a lot! I'm an American, but Dr. Who shows how to avoid so many pitfalls currently plaguing network television:* The fairy-tale start and the crazy introduction of the Eleventh Doctor create the exact right suspension of disbelief. Network shows, too often, either take things so seriously that the audience (also serious) questions everything, or is so tongue-in-cheek that it doesn't seem at all real. Not Dr. Who! Everyone sells the situation, even the "terror" of the Daleks, but there's enough humor that the audience plays along, which is as it should be. Heartbreak and humor! It's positively Whedonesque... or, more likely, Joss Whedon has Whovian elements to his work. Creativity may be faily timey-wimey itself.* The romance--oh, the romance! I like a good (preferrably happy!) romantic subplot to my television, which is why I'd avoided Who before now--as I understood it, the rare romance was generally unrequited? And yet on American television, shows like Bones tempt the audience with will they/won't they situations while all the time fleeing an imaginary "Moonlighting Curse." This season of Dr. Who blew that away. The Amy/Rory romance. The Doctor/River romance. They weren't allowed to overwhelm the story (duh), but they were completely satisfying.* The artistic unity. By the final two episodes, I was savoring the callbacks to previous episodes and how beautifully everything came back to form a perfect circle. No episode or secondary character had been wasted--which means Nothing Was Forgotten. Too often, American television seems to lose some of its continuity. This season of Dr. Who was absolute continuity. AND--they resolved everything. On an American network, the series would have ended with the 2nd to the last episode and the tragic cliff-hanger, as if audiences can't be expected to tune back in unless they're held hostage by a need to know. Dr. Who gave us an ending so satisfying that I'll be a repeat customer. What a concept?Finally--the time travel. I can take or leave the space aliens, but I do love a good time travel. As a huge fan of Audrey Niffeneggar's The Time Traveler's Wife, I loved how it flavored this season of Dr. Who, from the out-of-sync romance of River Song to the redheaded girl waiting for her time traveling friend to return. I've loved time travel television from Voyagers! to Journeyman, and this season of Dr. Who in particular has shot to the top of my list.Watch it.
summary: Perfect Time Travel TV -- American Shows Take Note!
